persons.name: Anaxagoras
persons.description: Greek Presocratic philosopher.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: Plutarch
persons.description: Greek writer most famous for his parallel lives of Greek and Roman statesmen and military leaders.

persons.name: Lysander
persons.description: A Spartan military and political leader. He destroyed the Athenian fleet at the Battle of Aegospotami in 405 BCE, forcing Athens to capitulate and bringing the Peloponnesian War to an end.

persons.name: SilenusCalatinus
persons.description: Sicilian Greek historian of Magna Graecia who wrote a history in Greek of Hannibal's campaign in Italy from 218 to 204 BC. His work is known only from fragments and borrowings by other authors.

persons.name: Daimachus
persons.description: Probably: Daimachus, Greek diplomat and writer.

places.name: Gos
places.description: Aegospotami is the ancient Greek name for a small river issuing into the Hellespont northeast of Sestos. According to Pliny and Aristotle, a meteor landed here in 467 BC after reports of a comet.

places.name: Thrace
places.description: Thrace is a geographical and historical region in Southeast Europe. Bounded by the Balkan Mountains to the north, the Aegean Sea to the south, and the Black Sea to the east, it comprises present-day southeastern Bulgaria, northeastern Greece, and the European part of Turkey, roughly the Roman Province of Thrace.

places.name: Athens
places.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

persons.name: PierreGassendi
persons.description: French philosopher, Catholic priest, astronomer and mathematician who published the first data on the transit of Mercury in 1631.

places.name: Provence
places.description: Provence is a region in southeastern France which borders the Mediterranean Sea and Italy.

places.name: Mount Vaisi
places.description: A mountain in the Alpes-Maritimes which was the site of a meteor fall in 1637. The coordinates given are approximate.

places.name: Verona
places.description: Verona is a city located on the Adige River in the north of Italy.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

places.name: Artois
places.description: a region of northern France.

places.name: Maine (France)
places.description: Maine is one of the traditional provinces of France. It corresponds to the former County of Maine, whose capital was also the city of Le Mans.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

persons.name: EdwardTopham
persons.description: English journalist and playwright, who publicized the Wold Cottage meteorite that fell on his property.

places.name: Mediterranean Sea
places.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

places.name: Rome
places.description: The capital of Italy.

places.name: Yorkshire
places.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

persons.name: JamesSowerby
persons.description: English naturalist and illustrator, a member of the Geological and Linnean  Societies. FRSL.

places.name: Yorkshire
places.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

places.name: Varanasi
places.description: a city in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh dating to the 11th century B.C. now known as Varanasi

places.name: Lyon
places.description: Lyon is the third-largest city in France. It is located at the confluence of the Rivers Rhône and Saône, to the north-west of the French Alps.

places.name: Siena
places.description: A city in Tuscany, and the capital of the Province of Siena.

places.name: Glasgow
places.description: Glasgow is a port city on the River Clyde in Scotland's western Lowlands.

places.name: Mauerkirchen
places.description: a municipality in the district of Braunau am Inn in the Austrian state of Upper Austria.

places.name: L'Aigle
places.description: L'Aigle is a commune in the Orne department in Normandy in northwestern France.

places.name: Bavaria
places.description: A German state.

persons.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Glasgow
places.description: Glasgow is a port city on the River Clyde in Scotland's western Lowlands.

places.name: United States
places.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

places.name: Glasgow
places.description: Glasgow is a port city on the River Clyde in Scotland's western Lowlands.

persons.name: Jacques Louis deBournon
persons.description: French born mineralogist who lived and worked in London. An Annual Subscribed to the Royal Institution, he was founder member of the Geological Society. FRSL.

places.name: Yorkshire
places.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

places.name: France
places.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

places.name: Varanasi
places.description: a city in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh dating to the 11th century B.C. now known as Varanasi

persons.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
persons.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: David BailieWarden
persons.description: Republican insurgent in the Irish Rebellion of 1798 and, in later exile, a United States consul in Paris.

persons.name: LukeHoward
persons.description: Quaker who published a nomenclature for clouds and meteorology. Part of partnership Allen and Howard, supplier of chemicals, pharmaceutics and apparatus. FRSL.

persons.name: Martin HeinrichKlaproth
persons.description: Pharmacist and chemist. Professor of Chemistry in Berlin. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JosephIzarn
persons.description: Author of Lithologie Atmospherique (1803) and inspector of French universities.

persons.name: EdmondHalley
persons.description: Astronomer and natural philosopher, who, using Newtonian mechanics, predicted the return of what became the eponymous comet. FRSL.

works.name: Des Pierres Tombées du Ciel: Lithologie Atmosphérique Présentant la Marche Et l'État Actuel de la Science sur le Phénomène des Pierres de Foudre, ... Tombées du Ciel, Etc
works.author: Joseph Izarn

persons.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
persons.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JohnPringle
persons.description: Physician who served as President of the Royal Society of London, 1772-1778. Created a baronet. FRSL.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
works.author: John Pringle

persons.name: ErnstChladni
persons.description: German physicist and musician who undertook pioneering work in the study of meteorites and invented Chladni plates.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
works.author: John Pringle

persons.name: JohnPringle
persons.description: Physician who served as President of the Royal Society of London, 1772-1778. Created a baronet. FRSL.

persons.name: BenjaminSilliman
persons.description: American chemist and science educator, professor at Yale College. Founded the American Journal of Science. Met Davy when he visited London in 1805.

places.name: Cape of Good Hope
places.description: The Cape of Good Hope is a rocky headland on the Atlantic coast of the Cape Peninsula in South Africa.

persons.name: Jahangir I
persons.description: Nur-ud-Din Muhammad Salim, known by his imperial name Jahangir ('Conqueror of the World'), was the fourth Mughal emperor, who ruled from 1605 until death.

places.name: Punjab, India
places.description: Punjab, a state bordering Pakistan, is the heart of India’s Sikh community.

places.name: Siberia
places.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges
